message:
Greetings geeks 

Lately , i found my self interested in game developing , so i wanna know what path should be taken in order to be a game developer ?

data.message:
My advice: a game developer IS as developer after all
How is you programming and logic skills?
work on these skills then begin with exploring easy game development studios like Unity3D or Unreal Engine etc.
Have fun, make a team and be creative :)
Very competitive, unless you are very  talented, avoid :)

Please take a look at this book 
http://gameprogrammingpatterns.com
this is a nice article about becoming a game programmer: http://gamesfromwithin.com/so-you-want-to-be-a-game-programmer
and from personal advice, i would say 1. go make games... there are THOUSANDS of tutorials out there, just go make games and see if you like it

2. try and figure out WHAT about game programming you like. AI is very different from networking, audio is very different from graphics and animations are very different from physics... and that is all without mentioning generalists / gameplay & tools programmers. Figure out which field you like and start looking into that

3. brush up on your low level skills. Do you know what happens to your variables down at the hardware level? Do you know how your functions are mapped in the memory? Can you take a wild guess at what your assembly looks like? If the answer is no to any of these work on making it a yes

4. Brush up on your maths. Algebra, calculus, spacial geometry, trigonometry, linear algebra (vectors, matrices & quats). Basically, if you think you know enough math, it means you dont. Can you work out the formula for the intersection of a sphere and a vector? Do you know how to project a shadow? go figure them out
5. Learn how to profile each area of your code properly and figure out where the bottlenecks are. Learn how to find out if your code is cpu bound / gpu bound / input bound or display latency bound.
and finally 6. Be willing to learn, passionate, open to criticism & with a true desire to improve
As a programmer on the cryengine, these are usually the parts I test candidates on during interviews :D
Finally, have fun, and good luck. It is very difficult, but nothing worth doing is ever easy
